The manufacturers have already stepped up their production and have committed funds to increase their capacity. Nevertheless, other factors, such as geography, climate, location of manufacturers and ports and transport, also impact on farmers' costs, as the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) pointed out.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important to note that all manufacturers have lowered their prices of all fertilisers and importers appear to be matching these prices. It has been implied that the local industry cannot meet the farming industry's demands for high analysis phosphatic fertiliser. The fact is that manufacturers are prepared to produce more high analysis phosphatic fertiliser. In any regard, phosphatic fertilisers are highly substitutable. The arguments as to which particular fertilisers to use are complex. They include price, types of trace element, ease of use and, indeed, what one's next door neighbour is using. Manufacturers have integrated plants. One could not expect single superphosphate to remain at the same price if large quantities of high analysis phosphate fertiliser were imported. The 66 per cent of farmers who use single superphosphate would be disadvantaged.

It is asserted that competition will be reduced because imports of fertiliser will be so much less and that this will lead to a monopolistic situation for Australian industry vis-a-vis imports. That has to be looked at very carefully.

The honourable member for Forrest (Mr Drummond) and the Deputy Leader of the National Party asserted that the measure effectively takes $55m from the rural sector and gives it to secondary industry. All Commonwealth fertilisers legislation subsidies are passed on in full, will need to be passed on in full and have always been passed on in full to the farmers. The Bill specifically requires the benefit of any subsidy payable to producers to be passed on to the end user purchaser. In addition, it makes registration of producers, which is a precondition to the receipt of subsidy, conditional on an undertaking by the producer that the benefit of subsidies will be passed on to the end user purchaser. Clause 10 provides that the Comptroller may direct that subsidy is not payable to a producer where the Comptroller is not satisfied that the price being charged by the producer in respect of sales of subsidised fertiliser is such as to pass on to a purchaser the full benefit of the subsidy.

In the years in which this subsidy package has been in operation no complaints have been received on the mechanism of passing on the benefit of the assistance from the producer to the end user consumer. This point is even admitted by the National Farmers Federation. Local producers are assisted by this Bill only indirectly through the potential to increase production. In fact, the $55m is not being shifted from the farmers to the local manufacturers. Again, as I said earlier, the aim of the subsidies is to increase consumption of fertilisers, not simply to assist the farmers, 25 per cent of whom, as I said, do not use the fertilisers. The honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan) suggested that the Government should model the fertilisers assistance on the diesel fuel rebate scheme. The scheme that is proposed assumes that either an import duty or an excise duty has been paid. It is these duties on which a rebate can be paid. No such duties are paid on fertilisers, so the analogy seems to fall.

The Government has made the decision to subsidise the cost of fertiliser in terms of a consumption subsidy payable to producers and then required, as I have said about four times, to be passed on to the end user consumer. The Government is constitutionally constrained, when it employs industries assistance via bounty or subsidy, to pay that bounty or subsidy on local production. The unique end use condition on this subsidy, however, ensures that the benefit of the government assistance is passed on.

At the moment we do not believe that there is a monopoly situation. Existing manufacturers compete vigorously where transport and other factors permit. Domestic industry, we repeat, can provide the full range of phosphate and nitrogen fertilisers. The honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) asserted that the original intention of the Fertilisers Subsidy Bill was to give a consumption subsidy to assist farmers and that therefore the status quo should be retained. The intention of the subsidies, as I have said, is much broader than that.

The honourable member for O'Connor takes the view that the Government's action on fertilisers has led to price increases for farmers, entrenches the monopoly of the local manufacturers, is anti-rural, and in effect ignores the Government's commitments on fertilisers given in the economic and rural policy statement. Again, we believe that this is one of a number of industries that will be restructured, that we hope will be more efficient and that we hope will be more competitive. It is often very difficult, when representing the interests of farmers locally, to say `Take the big picture; look at what is happening to Australian industry overall', irrespective of what the sector is. As the honourable member and many members of the Opposition would be aware, we are going through a period of quite remarkable, quite dramatic change, and a number of industries which have been very weak will, I think, become very much stronger. Certainly it is not the intention that any industry that is currently strong, such as the agricultural sector, will be weakened in any way. I ask for the support of the House on this very important measure.
Question put:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on Publications, I present the report of the Committee relating to the review of the cost and distribution of the Parliamentary Papers Series, and I seek leave of the House to make a short statement in connection with the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the major functions of the Joint Committee on Publications is to advise on the administration of the Parliamentary Papers Series. The series is a collection of the principal papers presented to Parliament each year. The series is designed to ensure a number of things, including that adequate copies of parliamentary papers are available for the use of members and senators; that parliamentary papers are available for sale to the public; that each parliamentary paper is available to be bound at the end of the relevant year into a series of volumes and preserved in a convenient and accessible form as a permanent record; and, finally, that in accordance with the Parliamentary Papers Act persons who publish any paper which has been ordered to be printed are afforded protection against civil or criminal proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: This report is the first major review of the series conducted by the Joint Committee since its 1977 report. The Committee believes that this review is most timely. Although the implementation of the 1977 report's recommendations resulted in major savings in the printing expenditure of the parliamentary departments, the Committee notes that the cost associated with the series remains high. For example, the Parliament's expenditure on the series in the past financial year was some $630,000. In resolving to conduct this review in May 1985 the Committee was aware, not only of the costs associated with the series but also of the increasing number of papers included in the series and other administrative problems. In conducting the review the Committee examined these issues in the context of the papers included in the series, the production of pamphlet copies and bound volumes, and the distribution of each. The result of this work is a collection of wide-ranging recommendations designed to improve the administration of the series.

Today, I wish briefly to mention the recommendations relating to two major areas. I refer first to annual reports by departments and statutory authorities, and secondly and importantly to the use of advanced technology in the production of the bound volumes of the series. I come first to the question of annual reports. The Committee has become alarmed in recent years at the increasing number of organisations presenting prestige documents as annual reports. The Committee's previous work in relation to the production of annual reports clearly indicates that a simple, clear format is sufficient to meet the Parliament's needs. This guideline has unfortunately not been followed and the cost of these publications has added to the cost of the series.

The Committee considered a number of options to redress this problem and has proposed a package of recommendations to tackle the problem. The major thrust of the recommendations is to encourage departments and statutory authorities to print annual reports that meet Parliament's requirements for information and do so in a modest production style. Thus, the Committee has recommended that the current three class production system operated by the Australian Government Publishing Service be reduced to two, by omitting the middle range production standard. The Committee, however, has considered the presentation concerns of some departments and statutory authorities, and has recommended that this reduction in standards be accompanied by the upgrading of cover designs allowable under class one production. Further, it has recommended that organisations wishing to publish prestige documents annually can do so separately from the annual report. The Committee noted that ministerial co-operation would be vital in ensuring that departments and statutory authorities adhere to the production guidelines when printing annual reports. The Committee will seek this co-operation and will continue to monitor the annual reports which are tabled in Parliament.

The final component of the package was to recommend that the Government consider the introduction of an annual reports Act. The Committee believes that this Act should place a legislative requirement on federally funded organisations, not only to report on their activities and account for finances, but also to enforce the production standards which I have already outlined and have no need to repeat. The Act would link the current variations in legislative and other arrangements that exist relating to annual reporting requirements without over- riding the particular reporting provisions of the other legislation.

The second matter relates to the use of advanced technology in the production of bound volumes. The production of bound volumes is a major component of the costs associated with the series. Currently, there are 110 sets of the volumes prepared annually. The last completed set for 1981 cost $70,300 for binding alone. The Committee considered four principal options to reduce these costs. These options were, first, the issue of papers and the relevant indexes to enable recipients to undertake a self-binding program; secondly, the provision of bound volumes by subscription in order to recover the cost of production and binding; thirdly, the cessation of production and distribution of annual bound volumes of the series; and fourthly, the issue of a microform version of the bound volume. Those were the four options that the Committee looked at.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which option did you decide on?

—The honourable member for Throsby asks me which option we decided on. The Committee finally recommended a reduction in the number of bound volumes prepared annually to 27. This will result in a total cost saving of the order of $98,000 annually. That is not a sum to be sneezed at; it is not an insignificant amount. This option would, however, still maintain the four principles of the Series and the Committee also recommended that further work be done on the demand for bound volumes in microfiche. In examining the issue of micro- fiche, the Committee became aware of exciting new technology offering a range of options to hard copy as a means of conveying information. A substantial amount of evidence was taken on these mediums, including CD ROM, optical disc and computer technology. Although the evidence indicated that this technology was available in Australia, it is still very much in its infancy and currently it is not a viable option. The Committee will, of course, monitor developments in these areas and may at a later date be able to recommend that one of these methods be used for the series.

SPEECH.PARA: The Parliamentary Papers Series, although a costly production, is a vital record of the Parliament. The report of our Committee seeks to balance the competing concerns of achieving cost efficiency and maintaining the principles of the series. I wish to place on record my appreciation of the efforts of fellow members of the Committee in preparing this lengthy report, and also of the secretarial staff who have served the Committee so well. I have pleasure in commending this report to the House.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN SECURITY INTELLIGENCE ORGANISATION AMENDMENT BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 10 October.
Consideration of Senate's amendments.
Senate's amendments-
No. 1-Page 12, clause 23, lines 14 to 16, leave out the clause, insert the following clause:
Findings of Tribunal
``23. Section 60 of the Principal Act is amended-
(a) by omitting from sub-section (1) ``or as to the question to which the assessment relates''; and
(b) by inserting after sub-section (1) the following sub-section:

`(1a) The Tribunal shall not make findings in relation to an assessment that would, under section 61, have the effect of superseding any information that is, under sub-section 37 (2), deemed to be part of the assessment unless those findings state that, in the opinion of the Tribunal, the information is incorrect, incorrectly represented or could not reasonably be relevant to the requirements of security.'.''.
No. 2-Page 24, clause 39, proposed new section 92p, lines 5 to 9, leave out the proposed new section.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the amendments be agreed to.

The Australian Security Intelligence Organisation Amendment Bill 1986 has been returned from the Senate with two amendments and I shall deal with both of them together. The first amendment, which was introduced into the Senate as a Government amendment, relates to the Security Appeals Tribunal and is an exercise in fine tuning rather than a substantive change. Since this Bill passed through the House of Representatives there has been a decision by the Tribunal which did not allow a security report to go through to the decision maker and in fact altered the report and the extent of its content, even though the report itself was not incorrect. In a nutshell, the Government is of the view that it would be worth while for the whole of the report to go forward rather than have the Tribunal interposed in the sense that it decides what should go forward.

The Tribunal's function is to review adverse or qualified security assessments furnished to government agencies by ASIO. An adverse assessment contains opinion, advice or information which is or could be prejudicial to the interests of the person involved, together with a recommendation from ASIO that relevant action, such as the granting of a security clearance, be not taken. The qualified assessment contains opinion, advice or information, but does not contain a positive recommendation. The amendment proposes to clarify the effect of the Tribunal's findings in respect of information contained in a statement of grounds upon which an adverse or qualified security assessment is based. The efficacy of the process by which security-related decisions are made depends upon the decision maker having access to all relevant available material. Where material is provided by ASIO by way of security assessment, that material should become available to the decision maker unless it is incorrect or irrelevant. The amendment does not affect the Tribunal's power to include in its findings an opinion on the weight to be given to any particular information, nor does it affect the Tribunal's power to comment upon or make findings in respect of any opinion or advice of the Director-General contained in the assessment. The amendment makes clear that whatever findings of that kind may have been made, information provided in the assessment should go forward to the decision maker unless it is found by the Tribunal to be incorrect, incorrectly represented or not reasonably relevant to the requirements of security. The amendment compliments the other amendments to Part IV of the principal Act and I commend it to the House.

The second amendment was moved by the Opposition in the Senate with the support of the Australian Democrats. It proposed the deletion of proposed new section 92p. That section concerns the privileges of witnesses appearing before the Parliamentary Joint Committee on ASIO. The Government does not accept the totality of the arguments made by the Opposition in support of its amendments. However, it acknowledges that the question of privileges is covered generally by the Parliamentary Privileges Bill, recently introduced into another place. For that reason the Government will not oppose the amendment. However, I make the point at this stage that the Parliamentary Privileges Bill is not in place and so we are dealing with this matter before that Bill comes into place, although it has been introduced.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two of them have been introduced.

—Yes, two have been introduced, but the Opposition amendment to which, no doubt, the honourable member for North Sydney was privy, was moved on the basis that we should accept this amendment now because there would be adequate coverage of parliamentary privileges by legislation.
—We are not privy to anything that happens in the Senate.

—No, I take that point. I just point out that there is a slight gap at the moment because the Parliamentary Privileges Bill is not in place. Rather than delay this Bill, which is important, the Government accepts the Opposition amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the amendments. The Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) has outlined the reasons for them and the only point that needs to be made from this side of the House is to stress again our support for the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation and to say that it is a pity that the Government support given to ASIO does not extend to the Left, which still regards ASIO as something which it would get rid of rather than have around. We need ASIO, and I know that many Government members would take the same view. Unfortunately, quite a few members take quite the opposite view and that is something that needs to be said again and again so that Australians will understand that on the Government benches, for all the declared unanimity, there are three separate factions on matters such as ASIO. It is a pity that some of them do not come into the House from time to time and say what they really think.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the amendment be agreed to.

This amendment is required in respect of clause 30, which deals with existing appointments. This is a case in which the Criminology Research Act had to be amended to enable other appointments to be made. The question was to preserve existing appointments. Accordingly, the purpose of this transitional provision is to preserve the existing appointments of persons to the board of management of the Australian Institute of Criminology and to the Criminology Research Council. This would avoid the need, after the principal Act is amended, for fresh appointments to be made of existing members of the board and existing members of the Council. State members are appointed upon the nomination of appropriate State Ministers. We are preserving the status quo rather than having to make completely fresh appointments because of the Act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —We support the amendment. In doing so, I refer briefly to the work of Professor Richard Harding, the Director of the Australian Institute of Criminology, who is now retiring. I think everybody will agree that the work he has done has been most valuable. In referring to that work, I mention the criticisms he has made of the way in which the Government goes about dealing with criminal law and what he calls the criminal pie in this country. He recently listed 16 government agencies that have a finger, as he put it, in some part of the criminal pie. They are the Attorney-General's Department, the Department of the Special Minister of State, the Australian Customs Service, the Health Department, the Department of Territories, the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, the Department of Transport, the Australian Taxation Office, the Department of Social Security, the Australian Federal Police, the National Police Research Unit, the National Crime Authority, the Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions, the Australian Law Reform Commission, the Office of Youth Affairs and the Department of Foreign Affairs.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem is well illustrated by the saga of the Taillon amendment. Honourable members of this House will recall that a Mr Taillon came to this country in July 1985. He was in transit from Bombay to Canada. Eleven kilos of hashish, worth an estimated $300,000, were found in his suitcase. But Mr Taillon was in transit and was not prosecuted because there were doubts as to whether or not he had committed an offence. I think all of us would believe that it is an astonishing state of affairs that because a person is in transit, and because he may not be carrying baggage in his hand, he can use Australia as a convenient conduit for the purposes of smuggling hashish, cocaine or anything else between one friendly country and another friendly country, or indeed between unfriendly countries.

This matter came to the attention of the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) and Senator Button. Each had a finger in that particular pie. Let me remind the House of what has taken place. Nothing has taken place. Nothing has happened. The Government has said it has a commitment to stamping out organised crime. We all recall how high on the list of commitments is the Government's detestation of organised drug running. We share that view, but where is the action? On 24 September this year Senator Button was asked a question in the Senate about the loophole that was thought to exist in the Customs Act. He said this in the other place:
The matter is in the hands of the Attorney-General and I will obtain an answer to the honourable senator's question from him.
The question was: `What is happening?' On 9 October the Attorney-General in this House was asked a question on the same subject. He stated:
Because the importation aspect is not a matter within my portfolio but one for the Australian Customs Service, that opinion-
I interpolate and say that he was referring to an opinion that had been obtained from a Sydney Queen's Counsel on this loophole-

and advice has been forwarded to my colleague the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button. I understand that arrangements are now in place to amend the Act to ensure that, whether a case relates to importation and/or possession, prosecution can be launched.

Senator Button thought the Attorney-General was dealing with it and the Attorney-General thought Senator Button was dealing with it. It is now November 1986. The act took place in July 1985. The amendment that is required is a very simple one, and nothing has happened. Time and again we are told of this Government's commitment to stamping out organised crime, to dealing with drug offenders and various other matters in the area of organised crime. The best way to test things is to say: `Well, what have you done?' If there is a simple and obvious loophole, what do we do? We move quickly to shut that simple and obvious loophole. That has not taken place.

I conclude by saying that there are two things the Government can do: It can act swiftly to deal with obvious loopholes and, at the same time, it can state what its view is on the recommendations that have been made by royal commissioners such as Stewart and Costigan, recommendations by special prosecutors Gyles and Redlich and others so that we have an informed view of what the Government intends on recommendations, some of them made years ago, which have been allowed to gather dust in the archives of the Government. That is the first thing it can do if it is serious. The second thing it can do if it is serious about organised crime is to tell, in broad terms, what its strategic plan is for dealing with organised crime. Unless we have an understanding and a plan for dealing with such simple things as closing loopholes, it is perfectly plain that we can have no overall strategy whatsoever for dealing with organised crime.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Briefly, in answer to what the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) has said, I think he was absent when we were last debating the Taillon case. Whilst the honourable member raised this matter, I think it was subsequently raised by the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp) in the debate on the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill, which dealt with a number of matters.
—That was drugs through the post?

—No, I answered during the debate and, in fairness, I do not think the honourable member had a chance to listen to the answer. It went something like this: I took a view as the first law officer that there was no reason at all why the Director of Public Prosecutions should not have proceeded with the prosecution of Taillon. In other words, Taillon was charged and the charge was not proceeded with on the basis that there was some doubt, because the narcotics were found in the baggage, whether that was possession. I took the view that we should have proceeded with it. I got the opinion of Mr Porter QC, who said: `Yes, it could have been proceeded with'. To that extent I can understand the honourable gentleman legitimately raising the issue, but I want to make the point that there was no neglect. The issue is that the Director of Public Prosecutions, of his own initiative, thought there was a gap in the law, but I do not think the gap was there. Nevertheless, what the honourable gentleman said is true. I referred the matter to the Australian Customs Service, and I am making no excuses. The Customs officers took the rather unusual view-I think it is a quite extraordinary view-that it might be better to allow the narcotics to proceed overseas so that, from an intelligence point of view, they might be able to trace the other people who might be interested in getting the baggage, or matters of that nature. I regarded that as being fallacious and to that extent I did have an objection to that view. My view now prevails. The Minister, my colleague, agrees with me, and there will be an alteration to the Act to cover any suggested loophole.

SPEECH.PARA: I can understand the reasons raised about delay but, quite frankly, there was a conflict in the departments as to the need for the amendment, and originally it arose on the basis that a charge was not proceeded with when I think it could have been. That is the fundamental issue. The only thing to gather dust-I do not want to be too offensive to my colleague opposite because he did not have the real responsibility-was the effort to get extradition treaties, which were left in drawers at the time the Opposition was in government. We have negotiated 22 extradition treaties already, which is a record in view of the fact that only eight were ever negotiated in the previous 84 years of Federation. That gives honourable members an idea of how we should focus on the problems of crime. The honourable gentleman is right to raise the matter. We have to have negotiations, understandings, co-operation and treaties with other countries. We have also negotiated with a number of countries what are called mutual assistance treaties, particularly within the Commonwealth, and we will pick up 47 in one hit. We took the initiative and raised these matters at the Milan conference. We took the initiative at the conference in Zimbabwe to get them agreed to. We are also in the process of negotiating mutual assistance treaties with the United States of America and Switzerland which will be of untold benefit in a number of areas, not the least of which might relate, of course, to insider trading which is of some interest in view of recent happenings in Australia.

I just make the point that the law needs to be fast, up to date and modern. We are in the process of doing this. Of course, at times the bureaucracy cannot see any need to change and that is a problem. We are having the same difficulties. If we are to talk about following the money trail, which we need to do, we want the financial institutions and structures in this nation to co-operate in what we would call the reporting of cash monetary transactions of $10,000 or more. Already they are objecting on the basis that it will be onerous and too difficult. But it is not too difficult or too onerous in the United States and we need their co-operation. At the moment that is the only thing that is holding us up from introducing further legislation which would relate to matters which I think are of paramount importance. I understand that the honourable gentleman is anxious that matters be proceeded with and so am I. I am hoping that those matters can certainly be brought to debate in this House early in the autumn session.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity to raise one matter with the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen). My recollection is-I do not have the report before me so I must rely upon my recollection-that the Director of Public Prosecutions, in his most recent report, referred to an interdepartmental study of the Costigan recommendations which I believe he said was included in about July last year. That interdepartmental examination has not seen the light of day. My recollection is that he said: `I was a member of it', that is, the Director of Public Prosecutions was a member of it, and that he would be interested in knowing what was happening. I raise that question again in the context of delay, just as I raised the Taillon amendment. I have heard what the Attorney-General has said. I am glad that we will have an amendment. I point out that we will not have one this session and, if there is any doubt on the subject, it will be one and a half years before that doubt is closed. It could be closed very quickly. Regardless of what views the bureaucrats may take amongst themselves as to what should be done, the Minister must make a decision. Ministers were aware of this problem back in July 1985. I would be very glad if the Attorney-General could indicate what is happening in regard to this interdepartmental examination of Costigan's recommendations, some of which go back, I believe, to as late as the latter part of 1983 and all of which were included in his final report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly arranged for the Director of Public Prosecutions to be a member of the interdepartmental committee. As I understand the position, the IDC could not really agree on a number of matters. For example, the Australian Taxation Office is adamant that section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act, the secrecy provisions, should not be altered to comply with what Mr Costigan recommended. Also, at that stage-this is not a criticism of Treasury-the view of Treasury on the IDC was that it would be inappropriate, unwieldy or cumbersome to have access to financial transactions. This is one of the views we have tried to change. That view is supported by the financial institutions themselves. They regard it as being difficult and cumbersome. That is one of the big factors and it is the only matter that is outstanding at present.

SPEECH.PARA: From my point of view, I see complete validity in what Mr Costigan has recommended. Other departments see legislation which is being passed by the Parliament as giving certain secrecy provisions and confidentiality to returns such as this and they do not think the law ought to be altered. I think we will be debating that matter quite fulsomely in autumn.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS AND DEFENCE

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 25 November, on motion by Mr Peter Morris:
That the House take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —No issue is of greater importance to the world than the issue of peace and security. In our nuclear age disarmament and arms control are issues involving our very survival on earth. It is the gravest responsibility of any government to do all it can to defend peace so that our ideals of freedom and justice can thrive in an environment of security. The aspiration to banish the spectre of nuclear war is shared by all civilised human beings for we are faced with a basic truth. Stated simply and eloquently by President Reagan it is:

SPEECH.PARA: A nuclear war cannot be won and must never be fought.

Although the coalition disagrees with a number of areas in the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence that is before the Parliament now, the fact that it has been presented to the Parliament underscores the deep concern that all of us in this House, and indeed in the Parliament, have for such crucial issues. But preserving peace means more than avoiding catastrophe. In our pursuit of peace and arms control we must not forget our responsibility to do our part in defending our values in a world where free societies are the exception and not the norm. We are committed to arms control but it is a commitment based on neither naivete nor wishful thinking. It is based on the conviction that whatever the difference between ourselves as a member of the Western alliance and the Soviet Union, we share a profound and overriding common interest in the avoidance of nuclear war and the survival of the human race.

A responsible disarmament policy must include both strong deterrence and active pursuit of arms control to restrain competition and make the world safer. But we must understand that our endeavour to control armaments and their proliferation does not operate in a vacuum. It is but a dimension of international politics and cannot be divorced from its political context. Arms control cannot resolve the geopolitical and ideological conflicts that lead to competitive arming in the first place. By itself, it cannot deliver security or prevent war. Arms, of course, are the product, not the cause, of East-West tensions. Disarmament can be successfully achieved only when these tensions are eliminated. In this regard we applaud the determination of the United States of America to press the Soviet Union for progress in resolving regional issues and for better respect for human rights. Without these it is difficult to build the confidence necessary for arms control negotiations to be successful. While arms control agreements themselves can contribute to reducing tensions, basic stability must underlie the political relations between the super-powers or else the process of arms control may not even survive.

Of course, we have to be realistic. The nuclear age cannot be undone or abolished. As Secretary of State Shultz said last week in Chicago, it is `a permanent reality'. Nuclear knowledge is now universal. It is growing and it is irreversible. However, although the threat of nuclear conflict can never be wholly eradicated, it can be vastly diminished. Our arms control efforts must be guided by four basic objectives: Firstly, reductions; secondly, equality; thirdly, stability; and, fourthly, verifiability. Let me deal briefly, firstly, with reductions. The agreements we seek should not merely aim at freezing existing levels of weapons and forces but must actually constrain the military capabilities of the super-powers and substantially reduce their weaponry and forces. The second objective is equality. These reductions should result in equal or equivalent levels of forces on both sides. An agreement that legitimises an unequal balance of forces creates instability and actually increases the risk of conflict. The third objective is stability. Arms control measures must genuinely enhance the stability of deterrence in crises. This means that after reductions each side's retaliatory force should be secure enough to survive if the other side strikes first. Hence, under stable conditions the temptation to fire first in a confrontation is minimised. Fourthly, verifiability: Arms control agreements must include provisions for effective verification of compliance by all parties. Experience has shown us that agreements lacking such provisions are futile and in themselves become a source of tension and mistrust. The net result must be unambiguous and effective provisions providing the maximum incentive for strict compliance.

The subject of verification is a major area of the coalition's dissent with the Sub-committee's report before the Parliament. The report failed to provide sufficient emphasis on the massive barriers to progress in disarmament and arms control which arise from the closed and secretive nature of Soviet society and the consequent impossibility of assessing arms control compliance when, in the USSR, the very means of verification are withheld. Verification involves the means to observe and detect an opponent's adherence, and compliance involves the adherence, whether detected or not. Both are equally critical. Proposals have to build confidence. In the jargon of the disarmament professionals, they must be transparent. They must be devised in such a way that the participants can be confident that the agreements that they enter into will be fully honoured by treaty partners. If agreements do not contain proper verification and compliance measures they are doomed to be ineffective.

Soviet intransigence on critical verification issues constitutes a major and continuing barrier to progress towards genuine disarmament. The Soviets fail to accept verification measures where they really count-in chemical weapons, nuclear weapons and nuclear tests. Moscow's continued obduracy on on-site inspection raises the obvious and worrying question: What do the Soviets have to hide? Bluntly speaking, meaningful arms control cannot be achieved without compliance, and compliance is impossible to determine in a closed society like the USSR without verification.

While proposing the complete abolition of nuclear weapons by the year 2000, Soviet General Secretary Gorbachev has not indicated even in the most general terms how such a ban would be verified. This is not a trivial point, since cheating becomes far more dangerous as nuclear weapons levels move towards zero. When cheating becomes more dangerous, verification becomes more important and must involve a commitment to agree to intrusive verification procedures, procedures which the Soviets to date have always totally opposed. Adequate verification is not merely a slogan, or an optional extra. Rather, it is a crucial factor in any disarmament agreement. Verification is in everyone's interest. The acceptance of obligations under an arms control agreement is in itself a recognition that states are willing to circumscribe their sovereign rights in this regard. Verification may appear to be a further encroachment on sovereignty, but it is only by accepting such measures that arms control can be effective and confidence would strengthen between states. It is imperative for the sake of arms control that we make it clear to the Soviets that a record of strict and literal compliance is essential to continuation of the arms control process.

We categorically reject another of the primary assumptions upon which this report is based, namely, the equation of the two super-powers on the same moral level. The adoption of such a spurious `evenhandedness' defies not only history but morality and our basic national security interests. A further significant flaw in the report which cannot pass without comment is the incoherence in its analysis of what is necessary to ensure that deterrence is effective. We agree that the stress must be on the importance of avoiding nuclear war. That has to be the stress. But the disarmament process is only one part of the answer. The other is the continuing role of a viable deterrence policy. Deterrence serves as the essential regulating principle for arms control. There then follows from deterrence the ideal of disarmament, that is, a symmetrical diminution of nuclear stockpiles so that they may continue to deter each other as they are reduced.

Australia's own security is intimately bound up with the security of the Western alliance and the viability of deterrence. The most menacing threat to Western security is weakness. Any scheme for dealing with the nuclear balance that would disarm, even in part, only one side or upset the balance between the two sides would leave us more, not less, exposed. In any discussion on disarmament we have to avoid the temptation-indeed, we would say the folly-of assuming that unilateral concessions and restraints on the part of the Western alliance would inspire reciprocal restraints from the Soviet Union. The West's capacity to succeed on arms control is, in our view, contingent upon and underwritten by its strength, its resolve and its ability to convey to the Soviet leadership its ability to deter, its capacity to seek new means of deterrence and its unity of purpose.

Deterrence at this time remains the only effective and viable restraint to nuclear conflict. The report gives inadequate recognition, in our view, to the defence capabilities required in the Western alliance for deterrence to be realistic and effective. It gives inadequate recognition to the fact that the international deterrent has played the pivotal role in preventing world war for the past 41 years. We must pursue every responsible path leading to reduced world tension and to disarmament. In pursuing a more stable world, however, we remain consistent in our belief that Australia's relationship within the Western alliance is absolutely fundamental to our position in international relations. We, of course, must recognise that Western unity, in our view, is a vital prerequisite for arms control progress and for ensuring that the Soviets negotiate seriously. When the West is in disarray, it only encourages the Soviets to prolong negotiations and to seek every opportunity to exploit divisions within the Western alliance.

I now wish to turn briefly to the report's assessment of the strategic defence initiative. The coalition rejects the report's negative assessment of the SDI research programs and its recommendation that Australia not participate in such research. We should be very clear that the strategic defence initiative offers the possibility of a better, more stable deterrence based on defences that are survivable. It has the moral aim of substituting a non-nuclear defence system to combat a nuclear offensive system. I underline that it is an endeavour to substitute a non-nuclear defence system to combat a nuclear offensive system. It is a necessary and prudent response to the Soviet Union's own intense research into similar technologies.

However, the report before us, in which we participated, fails to sufficiently emphasise such Soviet research. Since the 1960s the Soviet Union has been engaged in research into advanced technologies for strategic defence, including high energy lasers, particle beam weapons, radio frequency and kinetic energy weapons. These are the same technologies that the West, after more than 17 years of Soviet research, is now embarking upon. History is littered with examples of sceptics of progress. How many times in our history has human ingenuity overcome human expectations and even expert predictions? To take just a few examples, Thomas Edison forecast:
Fooling around with alternating currents is just a waste of time, nobody will use it-ever.
Admiral William Leahy, Chief of Staff to President Truman, in 1945 warned:
The atomic bomb will never go off, and I speak as an expert in explosives.
One scientist argued in 1932:
There is not the slightest indication that nuclear energy will ever be obtainable. It would mean that the atom would have to be shattered at will.

That scientist was Albert Einstein. So, SDI technology is in its infancy. It goes without saying that the research requires major technological breakthroughs but, if successful, it offers us all the hope of an historic transition to a world in which the most sophisticated technologies can be applied against weapons of mass destruction and not against people. It provides an incentive to the Soviets to agree to deep reductions in offensive weapons, and to honour these agreements in the future. (Extension of time granted) I thank the House for its courtesy and shall ensure that I do not hold up the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Kent) much longer. I thank my colleague the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) for his continuing co-operation.

SDI's purpose is quite clear. It is not for the purpose of aggression, as its critics argue, but is rather for the purpose of strengthening deterrence by denying the potential rewards of aggression. It is consistent with present treaty obligations, including the Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty. When the Soviets expressed to the Americans at Reykjavik their concern that SDI would be exploited to their disadvantage, President Reagan responded with an offer to share the benefits of strategic defence. It offers us all a potential key in unlocking a new future in arms control.

In the few minutes remaining, I want to turn to an area of direct concern to Australia, and a subject of the report to which the coalition cannot agree. In particular, we do not accept the report's recommendation that the South Pacific nuclear free zone enhances our security. We reject the report's overly optimistic assessment of the benefits to Australia. The zone can only upset the global balance by contributing to a weakening of the West's nuclear alliance. It undermines existing security arrangements-particularly ANZUS-and thereby leads to an overall reduction in regional security. A nuclear war, wherever it occurred, would have catastrophic consequences for Australia, for there is no escape in nuclear free zones and in simply wishing we could opt out.

The report implicitly denies the likelihood of a deteriorating regional environment and the consequences for Australia, and quite unnecessarily legislatively constrains our ability to respond to what conceivably could be a radically altered strategic environment. The Government, in supporting this Treaty, has placed itself apart from its responsibility to maintain a united resistance to the expansion of Soviet power. It has failed to appreciate that a principal Soviet aim throughout the post-war period has been to divide the Western alliance. The Soviet Union has always tried to develop and exploit differences within the Western alliance, leaving us to negotiate among ourselves while it sits back and waits for unilateral concessions that it need not reciprocate. The Soviet Union must understand that efforts to divide the Western alliance will not work, for unity is essential to the success of any East-West arms negotiations.

The issues we are dealing with are exceptionally difficult and complex. Arms control is never easy, and it is important to keep expectations in check. Reykjavik confirmed that negotiations would continue to be difficult as long as the Soviet Union attempts to hold progress on intermediate range and strategic nuclear arms hostage to movement in SDI research. Ultimate success in arms reduction efforts depends on a credible deterrent; strong, united alliances; responsible international behaviour by the Soviets; and a willingness by all to compromise in recognition of our overriding mutual interest in the survival of civilisation.

I conclude by thanking the Chairman and members and senators who have worked so hard on this momentous document. We have put in our dissenting report and others have dissented from the majority report, but together we have sought to put before the Australian people some differing views and in some cases some united views on the overridingly important subject of disarmament. I join the others who spoke yesterday in thanking Dr Graham Cheeseman, the defence adviser to the Sub-committee, and Dr Lee Kerr, Secretary to the Committee, as well as the other staff who assisted in compiling the report. It is a report which, despite our differences, can only serve to enhance constructive and, I trust, meaningful debate on this crucial subject.

The reason for that is very simple. The United States does not have a non-nuclear navy; it does not have non-nuclear ground forces; it does not have a non-nuclear air force. In general terms, most of its aircraft are nuclear capable, and for the convenience of its adversaries, since we are talking about adversaries, it does not signal very clearly which are nuclear capable, which are nuclear armed and which are not. There is one thing, however, on which we can all agree. We can all agree on the great problem posed by nuclear weapons. It is immense, and it is one of the great issues of our day because, by some means or other, in the decades to come, we must solve that problem. It is one that has interested me for many years. Over the last four or five years when I have gone to Washington, DC, I have seen Mr Paul Nitze on some four or five occasions. In the debate we tend to focus simply on the difficulties of the nuclear negotiations between the United States and the USSR. There are major difficulties there, but one thing on which we should focus somewhat more is the problem presented by the proliferation of nuclear weapons to smaller states. In a sense that could be much more dangerous for the world than the great arsenals which the major powers presently have. The reason is very simple. The major powers have been living with these great arsenals for upwards of 30 years. They have managed things well enough, in the sense that there has been no use-indeed, no averred or possible use-of nuclear weapons. They understand the immense risks that nuclear weapons pose. What would be the consequence if nuclear weapons got into the hands of some of the regimes that exist around the world? One does not have to name the regimes in detail; one understands immediately what the problem is.

There are inherent difficulties in the negotiations between the United States and the USSR. Let me name just a few. First, one has to determine what is in and what is out; what is counted for the purpose of negotiations and what is not counted. Next there is the problem of the differing view, the differing force structure, between the United States and the USSR. The United States relies on its trio-that is, submarine launched ballistic missiles, land based ballistic missiles and its air force. If one looks at the figures on the military balance issued for 1986-87 by the International Institute for Strategic Studies, one immediately sees the problem. The US has a total of 2,110 deployable intercontinental ballistic missiles. The Soviets have some 6,420 ICBMs. That, of course, raises a very real difficulty in negotiations. The Americans have a greater spread; the USSR has a greater concentration on ICBMs.

When I saw Mr Nitze in the middle of last year I was struck by something that he said, and I will repeat it here because amongst Australians, amongst people in the democracies, there is a sense of frustration, a feeling that all we need is an agreement, whatever that agreement may be. Of course, it is extraordinarily dangerous to come to an agreement simply for the purpose of coming to one. After all, we have had only two agreements-SALT I and SALT II. We know that SALT II was regarded by many as an agreement which was fatally flawed. Mr Nitze said:

The problem with negotiation on behalf of not only a democracy, but a coalition of democracies is that democracies want to progress so fast that they get impatient when things drag on, when the only way you can get a result is to be able to sit in the negotiations one day longer than the other fellow is willing to sit. That's easy if you're running a totalitarian state in a totalitarian alliance, but it isn't easy for a series of democracies.

That remains as true now as it was when he said it. Let me add a reference to what I said in August 1985 in an article I wrote in the Age. Looking at the prospects for nuclear negotiations leading to a treaty I said:
First we can put to one side for a very long time the prospect of abolition of nuclear weapons.
I do not think there would be any doubt about that. We would all like to see nuclear weapons abolished but it will not take place, at least for a very long time:
Next, we must not expect a quick agreement. On present signs, there is little prospect of anything substantial happening this year.

That was in 1985, and the same holds true for 1986. It may be that there will be a breakthrough, and that would be a very great achievement, but if one looks to a breakthrough one has to bear certain things in mind. First, the arsenals presently available are huge and therefore even a cut of say 50 per cent would not in any real sense make a great difference to the devastation that one side could inflict on another or that nuclear weapons overall could inflict.

The second thing that must be borne in mind, along with the remarks of the honourable member for Kooyong, is the difficulties posed by verification. The difficulties are made even more exigent these days with the increasing number of small weapons, in particular the cruise systems. Third, we need to understand that negotiations on nuclear weapons have to be tied in the longer term to negotiations on other systems. There is between the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation pact countries and the Warsaw pact countries a very severe imbalance of forces. Whether one is looking at ground forces, air forces, tanks or troops, the balance favours greatly and dangerously the Warsaw pact countries. We must move down the path of negotiations in a way which reflects the realities of the nuclear age. We cannot uninvent nuclear weapons, no matter how much we would like to. Since we have to live with them, just as we have to live with conventional forces, we must negotiate with a sense of reality and purpose, and an understanding that there are no quick solutions. If we are to maintain our freedoms it is essential that at the same time as we negotiate for reductions in nuclear arms, we maintain the strength of our conventional forces. The great distinction, aside from the freedoms, between the democracies and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics is that we do not seek to increase our power at the expense of others. We seek to safeguard rights. The Soviets seek to increase their power at the expense of others, and care not at all for the rights of others.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the reasons for the resignations is that the personnel concerned are not sure what the Government wants. TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this House tonight to comment on vandalism of public telephones, which is a social problem of great concern to many constituents in my electorate. I suspect that it is also a matter of great concern to many of my colleagues. Telecom Australia has provided data for the year 1985-86 which shows that $19m was spent on maintenance of public telephones throughout Australia, with an estimated $8m to $10m of that directly attributable to vandalism and damage caused by theft of equipment and coinage. There can be little satisfaction for the people of New South Wales to learn that, of that Australia-wide figure of $8m to $10m for vandalism and theft-related repairs, $6m, or about two-thirds, occurs in New South Wales. I am informed that there are 12,100 public telephones throughout Australia and that, because of damage, about 1,000 of those are out of order at any one time. I do not know about other honourable members, but I constantly receive complaints from my constituents that often they have to tour their suburb looking for a public telephone in working order. I have checked that out myself and I know that it is true. It is very difficult to find a public telephone in working order in the Manly-Warringah area at any one time.
—What about at the Harbord Diggers?

—The public telephones in the Harbord Diggers are only available to members of that club and it has a very wide membership. Many people believe that all 1,000 of those unserviceable telephones are located in the area in which they are looking. I understand that more detailed figures are not available for vandalised and theft-related damage, but Telecom tells me that it undertook a survey of thefts from public telephones in the Chatswood district in Sydney over the 12 months to June 1986. In that period 255 phones were robbed in that area, with almost every piece of equipment subsequently needing substantial repairs. That rate of thieving is close to one theft every 1 1/2 days, a rate which, nationally, would explain why 1,000 public telephones are unserviceable at any one time.

SPEECH.PARA: I am told that the revenue from public telephones in 1985-86 was $73m, of which $24m came from New South Wales. Therefore in New South Wales there are about 4,000 public telephones earning $24m income but requiring in excess of $6m in maintenance a year to repair vandalised and theft-related damage. I have not been given any estimates for the actual loss of coinage from thieving, but it must run into many millions of dollars. These are the physical and financial costs. But of equal concern must be the emotional cost of the inconvenience caused to a community that cannot readily get access to a serviceable public telephone. When these intangible costs are added to the actual repair bills and the loss of coinage, Telecom, the Australian taxpayers and those seeking to use public telephones are facing very serious problems. I am confident that Telecom is giving this matter much consideration and I understand and appreciate that there are virtually no easy solutions, particularly when one acknowledges the social problems that are very likely at the core of this thieving and vandalism.

However, I wish to point out to the House that the public telephone is such an important means of communication for so many people that a solution must be found to substantially reduce the incidence of vandalism as such and also of damage resulting from the theft of coinage. In that light I wish to suggest that Telecom should consider the installation of STD public telephones only in very secure locations and that all other public telephones give access to local calls only on a no-charge basis. Such an arrangement would mean that most public telephones would not need to collect coins and thereby remove a very strong incentive of theft. I notice in my area that theft is the main reason for vandalism of the public telephones. I know I speak with the full support of my constituents in offering to have a selected area of my electorate used as a pilot project to conduct a cost-benefit evaluation of such a scheme. This is not a stupid suggestion, it is a very reasonable suggestion. I hope that Telecom will take it up. There is nothing more annoying, damaging or downright dangerous than to have the public telephone system destroyed by wanton vandalism or theft. It is a matter of great significance to thousands upon thousands of people throughout Australia and in my electorate. I urge Telecom to give this suggestion the very closest consideration.

That is what has been happening. As we have heard today during the debate on the matter of public importance, this is a Government that really has been throwing taxpayers' money away at a great rate. It is about time that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) acted upon his own words, which are that much of this expenditure is indefensible silliness. It is about time that the Government got off the monetary track and started to impose some real fiscal discipline into the Budget and bring things back into order so that we can get this country going again. On behalf of all those disadvantaged Australians who find themselves this year borrowing money from finance companies to pay for their Christmas presents, I make this plea to the Government: Get your house in order; get your act together for the advantage and benefit of disadvantaged Australians.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 29 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it necessary for both Houses of Parliament to approve any licences issued to permit the export of mineral sands extracted from areas listed on the national estate.
(2) Are minerals sands being exported from any such areas.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. However, before export approval may be granted, any proposal to export mineral sands from any area on the Register of the National Estate must be considered in terms of the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975. This is designed to ensure that the national estate is adequately protected for the benefit of future generations as well as for the present community.

(2) Export approvals have been given since 1975 in respect of mineral sands sourced from mining leases granted to Allied Eneabba in that year. The leases fall within two Reserves which were placed on the Register of the National Estate in 1978.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coleman Mr W.P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 16 April 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 2203 (Hansard, 18 March 1986, page 1552) in which the Minister stated that universities are self-governing bodies and Commonwealth Government permission is not required for them to participate in research programs which have the approval of the responsible university authorities, why did the Minister state in a question without notice on 9 April 1986 (Senate Hansard, page 1481) that as far as the Government is aware no universities are engaging directly in Strategic Defence Initiative research and as universities operate within Government policy the Government does not expect that they will.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 1 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a letter circulated to members of the Government by the Australian Association of Permanent Building Societies, dated 14 April 1986, alleging at least 6 errors of misrepresentations in a document entitled `Explanatory Notes to Constituent Queries' relating to the Governments housing package and, in particular to the Government's decision to lift the charges on savings bank home loans.
(2) Which department was responsible for the preparation of the document referred to in the letter.
(3) Which allegations of incorrect or misleading statements referred to in the letter are correct.
(4) What action has been taken to correct any errors in the document.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) The document was prepared by staff in my office, with advice on some factual aspects provided by the Treasury.
(3) The references in the original document upon which the AAPBS commented were:
(a) `Savings banks are also subject to Commonwealth taxation, building societies are not.'
(b) `No building society is stuck with a portfolio of 13.5% regulated loans.'
(c) `Many building societies now only have to lend 60% of their deposits for housing. In New South Wales building societies may now only hold 60% of deposits in housing.'

(d) `Building societies have not been affected by the collapse in deposits to the same extent as savings banks. In the three months to January savings banks deposits fell at an annual rate of 10.7% bringing the rate of growth over the year to January to 2.3% and falling. By contrast building society funds rose by 11%.'
(e) `The Commonwealth subsidy only restores the normal competitive position of savings banks. It does not put building societies at a relative disadvantage.'

(f) `The Commonwealth subsidy merely enables the banks to preserve their deposits to finance the existing portfolio of regulated loans and the subsidy only restores the normal competitive position of savings banks. The Commonwealth is not subsidising deregulated lending by any institutions. For instance, it will not be subsidising the housing lending of trading banks.'

(4) A revised document was issued under the title `The Government's Housing Decision, Explanatory Notes for Constituent Queries'. The references shown in 3 above were retained in the revised document with the exception of (a) and (c) which were omitted and there was a minor amendment in the reference in (d) from `10.7%' to `around 11.0%'.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coleman Mr W.P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 August 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has any Australian Government made any guarantees of financial assistance to African states bordering South Africa in the event that comprehensive economic sanctions are imposed against South Africa?
(2) If so, (a) to which African states and (b) for how much in each instance?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The Australian Government has not made any guarantees of financial assistance to African states bordering South Africa in the event that comprehensive economic sanctions are imposed against South Africa. The Government is continuing, however, to provide development and humanitarian assistance to Southern African countries both bilaterally and multilaterally including through the regional development body the Southern African Development Co-ordination Conference (SADCC).
One of the principal objectives of SADCC is to lessen regional economic dependence on South Africa. The Government supports and is contributing towards the fulfilment of that objective.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Apple and Pear Corporation: Licences

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 16 September 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Australian Apple and Pear Corporation decided to reduce the number of Victorian export licences; if so (a) from what date does the decision apply, (b) how many licences will be withdrawn, (c) why will they be withdrawn and (d) what criterion will determine such withdrawals.
(2) Has he or the Corporation discussed this decision or any impending decision with persons and companies affected by the changes.
(3) If no such decision has been taken, is a reduction of licences in Victoria under consideration.
(4) Is such a reduction being considered for any other State.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian Apple and Pear Corporation's policy is to restrict the number of exporters so as to improve Australia's overall export performance by assisting export co-ordination activities. The Corporation has advised me that for the next licensing period beginning on 20 January 1987, the Corporation considered 6 licences to be the optimum number for Victoria. However, after considering the 21 applications received the Corporation has decided to grant 12 licences for Victoria for the new period. This compares with the 17 existing licences. Allocations in accordance with the policy were made consistent with the eligibility criteria laid down in the Apple & Pear (Conditions of Export) Regulations (Amendment) 1986. Unsuccessful licence applicants have the right of appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal for a review of Corporation licensing decisions.

(2) When formulating the new policy the Corporation conducted extensive consultations with all sections of the industry, and adopted the policy only after it had been supported by the Australian Apple and Pear Growers' Association and the Australian Apple and Pear Shippers' Association. All existing licensees were fully informed of the Corporation's policy and intentions.
(3) See answer to (1).
(4) The Corporation has advised me that the policy has been applied to all States.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory Medical Board: Consumer Representative

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Territories, upon notice, on 17 October 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is a consumer representative to be appointed to the ACT Medical Board.

(2) Is it the role of the Board to (a) examine the medical qualifications of doctors for registration and (b) discipline doctors who have been guilty of a misdemeanor; if so, what role will a consumer representative have in these matters.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) A community representative is to be appointed to the Medical Board of the ACT. The person's brief will include, but will not be limited to, consumer matters.
(2) Yes, it is the role of the Board to:
(a) examine the medical qualification of doctors for registration; and
(b) discipline doctors who have been found quilty of unprofessional conduct or other offence under Section 30 of the Medical Practitioners Registration Ordinance 1930.
The Board also has other responsibilities. These include the investigation and determination of complaints made against medical practitioners and the review of accounts for fees for medical services.

Community representation on the Board will broaden the range of advice available to that body and will enhance its work, bearing in mind that one of the central aims of the Board is to ensure that the community's interest is protected through a high standard of care.
